hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "There are six courtesies due from a Muslim to another Muslim: To give Salam to him when he meets him, to accept his invitation when he invites him, to reply to him when he sneezes, to visit him when he is ill, to follow his funeral when he dies, and to love for him what he loves for himself."
question: What are the six courtesies that a Muslim should extend to another Muslim?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "There are six things due from the believer to another believer: Visiting him when he is ill, attending (his funeral) to him when he dies, accepting his invitation when he invites, giving him Salam when he meets him, replying to him when he sneezes, and wishing him well when he is absent and when he is present."
question: What are the responsibilities of a believer towards another believer in times of illness?

hadith-eng: from Nafi: "A man sneezed beside Ibn 'Umar and said: 'Al-Hamdulillah Was-Salamu 'Ala Rasulillah. (All praise is due to Allah, and peace upon the Messenger of Allah)'. So Ibn 'Umar said: 'I too say Al-Hamdulillah Was-Salamu 'Ala Rasulillah, but this is not what the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) taught us. He taught us to say: "Al-Hamdulillah 'Ala Kulli Hal (All praise is due to Allah in every circumstance)."
question: What is the significance of saying 'Al-Hamdulillah' after sneezing in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: The Jews used to sneeze in the presence of the Prophet (ﷺ) hoping that he would say: 'Yarhamukumullah (May Allah have mercy upon you).' So he said: 'Yahdikumullahu Wa Yuslihu Balakum (May Allah guide you and rectify your affairs).'"
question: What was the reaction of the Jews when they sneezed in the presence of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: that he was with some people on a journey, and a man among the people sneezed and he said: "As-Salamu Alaikum (peace be upon you)." So he (Salim) said: "'Alaika Wa 'Ala Ummik (upon you and upon your mother)." It seemed as if that bothered the man, so he said: "Indeed I have not said except what the Prophet (ﷺ) said; a man sneezed in the presence of the Prophet (ﷺ) and said: 'As-Salamu 'Alaikum (peace be upon you)' so the Prophet (ﷺ) said: ''Alaika Wa 'Ala Ummik (upon you and upon your mother). When one of you sneezes let him say: "Al-Hamdulillahi Rabbil-'Alamin (All praise is due to the Lord of all that exists)" and let the one responding to him say: Yarhamukallah (May Allah have mercy upon you)" and let him reply: Yaghfirullah Li Walakum (May Allah forgive me and you both)."
question: What is the proper etiquette for responding to someone who sneezes in Islam?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "When one of you sneezes let him say: 'Al-Hamdulillahi 'Ala Kulli Hal (All praise is due to Allah in every circumstance).' And let the one replying to him say: "Yarhamukallah (May Allah have mercy upon you).' And let him say to him: 'Yahdikumullah Wa Yuslihu Balakum (May Allah guide you and rectify your affairs).'"
question: What is the recommended phrase to say after sneezing according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that two men sneezed in the presence of the Prophet (ﷺ); he responded to one of them and did not respond to the other. The one who was not responded to said: "O Messenger of Allah! You responded to this person and did not respond to me?' So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "He praised Allah while you did not praise Him."
question: What is the significance of praising Allah after sneezing in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: from his father: "A man sneezed in the presence of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) while I was present, so the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Yarhamukallah (May Allah have mercy upon you).' Then he sneezed a second and third time. So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "This man is suffering from a cold.'"
question: What is the significance of saying 'Yarhamukallah' when someone sneezes?

hadith-eng: from his mother, from her father, who said: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Reply three times to the sneezing person. If he (sneezes) more, then if you wish reply and if you do not then do not.'"
question: How many times should one respond to a person who sneezes?

hadith-eng: that when the Prophet (ﷺ) would sneeze, he would cover his face with his hand or with his garment, and muffle the sound with it.
question: What is the etiquette of sneezing according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "The sneeze is from Allah and the yawn is from Ash-Shaitan. So when one of you yawns let him cover his mouth with his hand. For when he says 'Ah, Ah' Ash-Shaitan laughs from inside his opening." [And indeed Allah loves the sneeze and He dislikes the Yawn, so when a man says Ah, Ah when yawning, indeed Ash-Shaitan laughs from inside his opening."]
question: What is the significance of sneezing and yawning in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Indeed Allah loves sneezing and He dislikes the yawn. So when one of you sneezes and says 'Al-Hamdulillah (All praise is due to Allah),' then it is a right due from every one who hears him to say: 'Yarhamukallah (May Allah have mercy upon you)' As for yawning then when one of you yawns let him suppress it as much as possible and not say: "Hah Hah' for that is only from Ash-Shaitan laughing at him."
question: What is the significance of saying 'Al-Hamdulillah' after sneezing in Islam?

hadith-eng: from 'Adi - and he is Ibn Thabit - from his father, from his grandfather - [from the Prophet (ﷺ)]: "Sneezing, dozing and yawning during Salat, and menstruation, regurgitation and nosebleeds are from Ash-Shaitan."
question: What are some actions or occurrences during prayer that are considered to be from Ash-Shaitan?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Let one of you not have his brother stand from his seat then sit in it."
question: What ethical considerations should be observed when taking someone else's seat?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Let one of you not have his brother stand from his seat then sit in it."
question: What ethical considerations should be observed when taking someone's place in a gathering?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "A man has more right to his seat. If he leaves for some need of his, then he returns, then he has more right to his seat."
question: What is the significance of a person's right to their seat in a gathering?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "It is not lawful for a man to separate two people except with their permission."
question: What is the significance of seeking permission before separating two individuals?

hadith-eng: "There was no person more beloved to them than the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)." [He said:] "And they would not stand when they saw him because they knew that he disliked that."
question: What does this narration indicate about the companions' love for the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: that Mu'awiyah came out and 'Abdullah bin Az-Zubair and Ibn Safwan stood for him when they saw him, so he said: "Sit, I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) saying: 'Whoever wishes that he be received by men standing then, let him take his seat in the Fire.'"
question: What is the Islamic perspective on seeking respect and honor from others?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Five are from the Fitrah: Cutting the pubic hair, circumcision, paring the mustache, plucking the under arm hair and trimming the fingernails."
question: What are the practices considered part of the natural disposition (Fitrah) in Islam?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "Ten are from the Fitrah: Paring the mustache, leaving the beard to grow, Siwak, cleaning the nose with water, paring the fingernails, washing the knuckles, plucking the underarm hair, shaving the pubic hairs, and Intiqas with water."
question: What are the practices considered part of the natural disposition (Fitrah) in Islam?

hadith-eng: from the Prophet (ﷺ), that he (ﷺ) fixed the time as every forty nights for them to trimming the fingernails, taking from the mustache, and shaving the pubic hairs.
question: What is the recommended frequency for trimming fingernails in Islam?

hadith-eng: "[The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)] fixed the time for us paring the mustache, trimming the fingernails, shaving the pubic hairs and plucking the underarm hairs - that we not leave it for more than forty days."
question: What are the recommended grooming practices in Islam regarding personal hygiene?

hadith-eng: "The Prophet (ﷺ) would pare, or take from his mustache, and Ibrahim Khalilur-Rahman would do it (as well)."
question: What is the significance of trimming the mustache in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Whoever does not take from his mustache, then he is not from us."
question: What is the significance of grooming one's mustache in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: from his father, from his grandfather that he Prophet (ﷺ) would take from his beard; from its breadth and its length.
question: What guidance does Islam provide regarding grooming and maintaining one's beard?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Trim the mustache and leave the beard to grow."
question: What guidance is provided regarding the grooming of facial hair in Islam?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) ordered trimming the mustache and leaving the beard to grow.
question: What are the grooming practices recommended for Muslim men regarding facial hair?

hadith-eng: from his paternal uncle, that he saw the Prophet (ﷺ) reclining in the Masjid, and placing one of his feet atop another.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) behavior and demeanor in the mosque?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prohibited Ishtimal As-Samma, Al-Ihtiba in one garment, and that a man raise one of his feet atop the other while he is reclining on his back."
question: What are the specific prohibitions mentioned by the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) regarding certain postures or ways of sitting?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prohibited Ishtimal As-Samma, Al-Ihtiba in one garment, and that a man raise one of his feet atop the other while he is reclining on his back."
question: What are the specific prohibitions mentioned by the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) regarding certain postures or clothing?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) saw a man laying on his stomach so he said: "Indeed such laying is not loved by Allah."
question: What is the significance of body posture in Islam according to the teachings of the Prophet (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: "My father narrated to me from my grandfather, who said: 'I said: "O Messenger of Allah! Regarding our 'Awrah, what of it must we cover and what of it may we leave?" He said: "Protect your 'Awrah except from your wife or what your right hand possesses."' He said: "What about a man with another man?" He said: "If you are able to not let anyone see it, then do so." I said: "What about a man when he is alone?" He said: "Allah is most deserving of being shy from Him."
question: What guidelines are provided for covering one's 'Awrah in the presence of others?

hadith-eng: "I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) reclining upon as pillow, on his left side."
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) habits or practices from his posture while reclining?

hadith-eng: "I saw the Prophet (ﷺ) reclining upon a pillow."
question: What does the posture of reclining signify about the Prophet's (ﷺ) lifestyle or habits?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "A man is not lead in his dominion, and his seat of honor in his house is not sat in without his permission."
question: What is the significance of respecting a person's authority in their own domain?

hadith-eng: "I heard my father Buraidah saying: 'I was walking with the Prophet (ﷺ) when a man came to him with a donkey, so he said: "O Messenger of Allah! Ride" and the man moved toward the back. The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "No, you have more right to the front of your beast, unless you allot it for me." He said: "I have allotted it for you.'" He said: 'So he rode.'"
question: What does this narration teach about the etiquette of offering a ride to someone?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Do you have Anmat?" I said: "Where would we get Anmat from?" He said: "Soon you will have Anmat" He said: "I would say to my wife: 'Remove your Anmat from my sight.' But she would say: 'Did not the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) say: "Indeed you shall soon have Anmat?" He said: "So I left it."
question: What is the significance of the term 'Anmat' in the context of this narration?

hadith-eng: from his father who said: "I guided Allah's Prophet (ﷺ) and Al-Hasan and Al-Husain, on his gray mule until I brought him to the apartment of the Prophet (ﷺ), this one was in front of him, and this one behind him."
question: What can be inferred about the relationship between the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) and his grandsons, Al-Hasan and Al-Husain?

hadith-eng: "I asked the Messenger Of Allah (ﷺ) about the unintentional glance, so he ordered me that I divert my sight."
question: What guidance is provided for handling unintentional glances?

hadith-eng: from his father (from the Prophet (ﷺ)) who said: "O 'Ali! Do not follow a look with a look, the first is for you, but the next is not for you."
question: What guidance is given regarding controlling one's gaze in Islam?

hadith-eng: to Ibn Shihab, that Umm Salamah narrated to him, that she and Maimunah were with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), she said: "So when we were with him, Ibn Umm Maktum came, and he entered upon him, and that was after veiling had been ordered for us. So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Veil yourselves from him.' So I said: 'O Messenger of Allah! Is he not blind such that he can not see us or recognize us?' So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Are you two blind such that you can not see him?'"
question: What is the significance of veiling in the presence of non-mahram men in Islam?

hadith-eng: from the freed slave of 'Amr bin Al-'As that 'Amr bin Al-'As sent him to 'Ali seeking his permission to enter upon Asma bint Umais, so he permitted him. When he was finished from what he needed, the freed slave of 'Amr bin Al-'As asked about that, so he said: "Indeed the Prophet (ﷺ) prohibited us - or - prohibited that we enter upon women, without the permission of their husbands."
question: What is the significance of seeking permission before entering upon women in Islam?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "I have not left among the people after me, a Fitnah more harmful upon men than women."
question: What is considered the most harmful trial for men according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that he heard Mu'awiyah giving a Khutbah in Al-Madinah, and saying: "Where are your scholars, O people of Al-Madinah? [Indeed] I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) forbidding from these locks (of hair), and saying: 'The Children of Isra'il were only ruined when their women used them.'"
question: What is the significance of scholars in guiding the community according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) cursed the women who practice tattooing and those who seek to be tattooed, the women who remove hair from their faces seeking beautification by changing the creation of Allah.
question: What is the Islamic perspective on tattooing for women?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "Allah's curse is upon the woman who lengthens hair and the women who seeks to have her hair lengthened, and the woman who tattoos and the woman who seeks to have her herself tattooed."
question: What is the Islamic perspective on altering one's physical appearance through hair extensions and tattoos?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) cursed the women who imitate men and the men who imitate women."
question: What is the Islamic perspective on gender roles and imitation between men and women?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) cursed those men who behave effeminately and those women whose behavior is masculine."
question: What is the Islamic perspective on gender roles and behavior?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "Every eye commits adultery, and when the woman uses perfume and she passes by a gathering, then she is like this and that.'" Meaning an adulteress.
question: What is the significance of modesty in Islam, particularly concerning the use of perfume by women?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Fragrance for men is that which its scent is apparent and its color is hidden, and fragrance for women is that which its color is visible and its scent is hidden." (Meaning when leaving the home as indicated by the previous chapter. As far as in the presence of the husband, then the woman may wear fragrant perfume.)
question: What are the guidelines for men regarding the use of fragrance in Islam?

hadith-eng: "The Prophet (ﷺ) said [to me]: 'Indeed the best fragrance for men is what's scent is apparent and its color is hidden, and the best fragrance for women is what's color is visible and its scent is hidden.' And he prohibited Mitharatil-Urjawan (Mitharah was some type of saddle cloth. Some of the people of knowledge say it was a certain kind of cloth made of silk, and it preceded earlier under no. 1760. They disagree over Al-Urjawan, and perhaps it means whatever is red, meaning the Red Mitahrah, see Tuhfat Al-Ahwadhi)."
question: What are the characteristics of the best fragrance for men according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Anas would not refuse perfume, and Anas said: 'Indeed the Prophet (ﷺ) would not refuse perfume."
question: What is the significance of accepting gifts in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "There are three that are not refused: Cushions, oils [Duhn (fragrance)], and milk."
question: What are the three items mentioned that should not be refused when offered?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'When one of you is given some fragrance then do not refuse it, for indeed it comes from Paradise."
question: What is the significance of accepting gifts, particularly fragrance, in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "A woman is not to touch a woman such that she can describe her to her husband as if he is looking at her."
question: What guidance is provided regarding the privacy and modesty of women in interactions with others?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'A man is not to look at the 'Awrah of a man, and a woman is not to look at the 'Awrah of a woman. A man is not to be alone with a man under one garment, and a woman is not to be alone with a woman under one garment.'"
question: What are the guidelines in Islam regarding looking at the 'Awrah of others?

hadith-eng: from his father, from his grandfather, who said: "I said: 'O Prophet of Allah! Regarding our 'Awrah, what of it must we cover and what of it may we leave?' He said: 'Protect your 'Awrah except from your wife or what your right hand possesses.' He said: "I said: 'O Messenger of Allah! What about when some people are with others?' He said: 'If you are able to not let anyone see it then do not let them see it.'" He said: "I said: 'O Prophet of Allah! What about when one of us is alone?' He said: 'Allah is more deserving of being shy from Him than the people.'"
question: What guidelines are provided for covering one's 'Awrah in the presence of others?

hadith-eng: about his grandfather Jarhad, he said: "The Prophet (ﷺ) passed by Jarhad in the Masjid and his thigh was exposed, so he said: 'Indeed the thigh is 'Awrah.'"
question: What is considered 'Awrah for men in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: from his father, from the Prophet (ﷺ) who said: "The thigh is 'Awrah."
question: What is considered 'Awrah in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "The thigh is 'Awrah."
question: What is considered 'Awrah in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Ibn Jarhad informed me from his father, that the Prophet (ﷺ) passed by him while his thigh was exposed, so the Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Cover your thigh, for indeed it is 'Awrah.'"
question: What is considered 'Awrah in Islamic teachings for men?

hadith-eng: "I heard Sa'eed bin Musayyab saying: 'Indeed Allah is Tayyib (good) and he loves Tayyib (what is good), and He is Nazif (clean) and He loves cleanliness, He is Karim (kind) and He loves kindness, He is Jawad (generous) and He loves generosity. So clean' - I think he said - 'your courtyards, and do not resemble the Jews.'" He said: "I mentioned that to Muhajir bin Mismar, and he said: "Amir bin Sa'd [bin Abi Waqqas] narrated it to me from his father from the Prophet (ﷺ), similarly, except that he did not say: "Clean your courtyards."
question: What attributes of Allah are highlighted in this narration?

hadith-eng: from Laith, from Nafi, from Ibn 'Umar that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Beware of nakedness! For indeed there are with you, those who do not part from you except at the place of defecation, and when a man goes into his wife. So be shy of them and honor them."
question: What is the significance of modesty in Islam, especially in private moments?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, then he is not to let his wife enter the Hammam, and whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, then he is not to enter the Hammam without an Izar. And whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, then he is not to sit at a spread in which Khamr is circulated."
question: What are the guidelines for entering a Hammam according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: from 'Aishah, that the Prophet (ﷺ) prohibitied the men and women from the Hammamat (plural of Hammam), then he permitted it for the men in Izar."
question: What is the significance of the Prophet's initial prohibition of Hammamat for both men and women?

hadith-eng: that some women from the inhabitants of Hims, or from the inhabitants of Ash-Sham entered upon 'Aishah, so she said: "Are you those whose women enter the Hammamat? I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) saying: 'No woman removes her garments in other than the house of her husband except that she has torn the screen between herself and her Lord.'"
question: What is the significance of modesty and privacy for women in Islam?

hadith-eng: "I heard Abu Talhah saying: 'I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) saying: "The angels do not enter a house in which there is a dog or an object of images."
question: What is the significance of angels entering a house in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that Rafi' bin Ishaq informed him, saying: "I and 'Abdullah bin Abi Talhah entered upon Abu Sa'eed Al-Khudri to visit him. So Abu Sa'eed said: 'The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) informed us: "The angels do not enter a house in which there is an image or a picture."
question: What is the significance of angels not entering a house with images or pictures?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Jibra'il came to me and said: "Indeed I had come to you last night, and nothing prevented me from entering upon you at the house you were in, except that there were images of men at the door of the house, and there was a curtain screen with imagines on it, and there was a dog in the house. So go and sever the head of the image that is at the door so that it will become like a tree stump, and go and cut the screen and make two throw-cushions to be sat upon, and go and expel the dog." So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did so, and the dog was a puppy belonging to Al-Husain or Al-Hasan which was under his belongings, so he ordered him to expel it.
question: What are the implications of having images in a house according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "A man passed by while wearing two red garments. He gave Salam to the Prophet (ﷺ) but he did not return the Salam."
question: What is the significance of returning greetings in Islamic etiquette?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prohibited the gold ring, Al-Qassi, Al-Mitharah, and Al-Ji'ah (beer)."
question: What items or practices are prohibited in Islam according to the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) ordered us with seven things and he forbade us from seven. He ordered us to follow the funeral, visit the ill, reply to the sneezing person, accept the invitation, assist the oppressed, to help the one who made an oath, and to return the Salam. And he forbade us from seven things: From the gold ring, or ringlets of gold, silver vessels, wearing silk, Ad-Dibaj, Al-Istabraq, And Al-Qassi."
question: What are the seven actions that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) encouraged Muslims to perform?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Wear white, for indeed it is very pure and cleaner, and shroud your dead in it.'"
question: What are the benefits of wearing white clothing in Islam?

hadith-eng: "I saw the Prophet (ﷺ) on a clear night, so I looked at the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and at the moon, and he was wearing a red Hullah, and he looked better than the moon to me."
question: How is the physical appearance of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) described in Islamic narrations?

hadith-eng: "I saw the Messenger of Allah wearing two green Burud."
question: What significance do the colors of clothing have in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) went out during the morning wearing a Mirt made of black hair."
question: What type of clothing did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) wear on certain occasions?

hadith-eng: that his grandmothers Safiyyah bint 'Ulaibah and Dhuhaibah bint 'Ulaibah narrated to him, from Qailah bint Makhramah - and they were her wet nurses and Qailah was the grandmother of their father - his mother's mother - she said: "We came to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)" and she mentioned the Hadith in its entirety; "until a man came when the sun had rose up, so he said: "As-Salamu 'Alaika O Messenger of Allah!' So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Wa 'Alaikas-Salamu Wa Rahmatullah' and upon him - meaning the Prophet (ﷺ) - were two tattered cloths, which had been dyed with saffron and had faded, and he had a small date-palm branch with him."
question: What is the significance of greeting the Prophet with 'As-Salamu 'Alaika' in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prohibited saffron for men.
question: What is the ruling on men wearing saffron in Islam?

hadith-eng: "The Prophet (ﷺ) saw a man wearing Khuluq and said: 'Go and wash it, then wash it, then do not use it again.'"
question: What is the significance of the Prophet's instruction regarding the use of certain substances or items?

hadith-eng: from Ibn 'Umar who said: "I heard 'Umar mentioning that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Whoever wears silk in the world he shall not wear it in the Hereafter.'"
question: What is the significance of abstaining from wearing silk in this world according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) distributed some cloaks but he did not give anything to Makhramah. Makhramah said: 'O my son! Let us go to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).' So I went with him. He said: 'Enter and call him for me.'So I called the Prophet (ﷺ) for him, then the Prophet (ﷺ) came out wearing one of the cloaks. He (ﷺ) said: 'I kept this one for you.'" He said: "So he looked at him and said: 'Makhramah is pleased.'"
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) handle situations where someone felt left out or overlooked?

hadith-eng: from his father, from his grandfather who said: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Indeed Allah loves to see the results of his favors upon His Slaves.'"
question: What does it mean for Allah to love seeing the results of His favors upon His slaves?

hadith-eng: from his father: "An-Najashi gave the Prophet (ﷺ) two black plain Khuff. So he wore them, then he performed Wudu and wiped over them."
question: What is the significance of wearing Khuff in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: from his father, from his grandfather: "The Prophet (ﷺ) prohibited plucking gray hair. And he said: "It is the Muslim's light.'"
question: What is the significance of gray hair in Islam according to the teachings of the Prophet (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "The one whose counsel is sought is entrusted."
question: What is the significance of seeking counsel in decision-making?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'The one whose council is sought is entrusted.'"
question: What is the significance of seeking counsel in decision-making according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: from their father that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "An omen is in three: A woman, a dwelling, and a (riding) beast."
question: What are the three things mentioned as omens in the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Whenever there are three of you, then let two not converse in exclusion of their companion."
question: What is the significance of not excluding a companion in a conversation when in a group of three?

hadith-eng: that Abu Juhaifah said: "I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) (he was) white and turning grey. Al-Hasan bin 'Ali resembles him most. He had promised thirteen young she-camels for us, so we went to get them. When we arrived he had died without giving us anything. So when Abu Bakr (became the Khalifah) he said: 'If there is anyone to whom the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) made a promise, then let him come forth.' I stood to inform him about it, and he ordered that they be given to us."
question: What physical characteristics of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) are described in this narration?

hadith-eng: that Abu Juhaifah said: "I saw the Prophet (ﷺ), and Al-Hasan bin 'Ali resembles him the most."
question: Who is described as resembling the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) the most?

hadith-eng: "I did not hear the Prophet (ﷺ) mentioning both of his parents (that is including both in the saying "May my father and mother be ransomed for you") for anyone other than Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas."
question: What is the significance of the phrase 'May my father and mother be ransomed for you' in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did not mention both of his parents for anyone except Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas. On the Day of Uhud he said: 'Shoot, may my father and mother be ransomed for you.' And he said to him: 'Shoot! O young man.'"
question: What significance does the phrase 'may my father and mother be ransomed for you' hold in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) mentioned both of his parents to me on the Day of Uhud."
question: What significance does the mention of one's parents hold in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said to him: "O my little son."
question: What does the term of endearment 'O my little son' signify in the context of the Prophet's teachings?

hadith-eng: from his father, from his grandfather that the Prophet (ﷺ) ordered naming the child on the seventh day, removing the harm from him, and Al-'Aqq (removing the hair and slaughtering the animal for 'Aqiqah).
question: What is the significance of naming a child on the seventh day in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "The most loved names to Allah are 'Abdullah and 'Abdur-Rahman."
question: What are the most beloved names to Allah according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "The most loved names to Allah are 'Abdullah and 'Abdur-Rahman."
question: What are the most beloved names to Allah according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "I forbid naming with Rafi, Barakah and Yasar."
question: What are the names that are discouraged in Islamic tradition according to the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Do not name your boy Rabah, nor Aflah, nor Yasar, nor Najih, so that it may be said: 'Is he there?' and it may be said: 'No.'"
question: What are the implications of naming children with certain names in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: that Abu Hurairah conveyed to him that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "The most despicable (Akhna) name to Allah on the Day of Judgement is that of a man named King of Kings. (Malikil-Amlak)."
question: What is the significance of names in Islam and how can they affect one's standing on the Day of Judgement?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) changed the name of 'Asiyah, he said: "You are Jamilah."
question: What is the significance of changing one's name in Islam?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) would change abhorrent names."
question: What is the significance of changing names in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: from his father that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "I have some names: I am Muhammad, I am Ahmad, I am Al-Mahi, the one by whom Allah wipes out disbelief, I am Al-Hasir, the one whom the people are gathered at his feet, and I am Al-'Aqib, the one after whom there is no Prophet."
question: What are the different names of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) mentioned in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) prohibited that one use his name and his Kunyah; naming themselves Muhammad Abul-Qasim.
question: Why is it discouraged to use both the name and Kunyah of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) together?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ): "When you name yourself after me, then do not use my Kunyah."
question: What is the significance of naming conventions in Islam, particularly regarding the use of certain names and titles?

hadith-eng: that he said: "O Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)! If I have a son after you do you think I could name him your Kunyah?" He said: "Yes." So he said: "So that was permitted for me."
question: What is the significance of naming a child after someone in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Indeed some poetry is wisdom"
question: What is the significance of poetry in conveying wisdom in Islam?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Indeed some poetry is wisdom".
question: What is the significance of poetry in conveying wisdom in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had a Minbar placed in the Masjid for Hassan to stand to boast (poetically) about the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)" - or she said: "to defend the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). And the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Indeed Allah has aided Hassan with the holy spirit (Jibril) as he boasts about - or - defends the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).'"
question: What is the significance of poetry in defending the honor of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng:
that the Prophet (ﷺ) entered Makkah during 'Umratil-Qada and 'Abdullah bin Rawahah was walking in front of him reciting verses of poetry.
"O tribes of disbelievers get out of his way - today we will strike you about its revelation; a strike that removes the heads from the shoulders - and makes the friend not concerned about his friend."
'Umar said to him: "O Ibn Rawahah! Before the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), and in the sanctuary of Allah you utter poetry?" the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Leave him O 'Umar! For it is quicker upon them than the raining arrow."
question: What is the significance of poetry in Islamic tradition, especially during significant events?

hadith-eng: from his father, that 'Aishah was asked: "Did the Prophet (ﷺ) used to say any poetry?" She said: "He would say parables with the poetry of Ibn Rawahah, saying: 'News shall come to you from where you did not expect it.'"
question: What is the significance of poetry in the life of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "The best statement spoken by the Arab is the saying of Labid: 'Everything aside from Allah perishes.'"
question: What is the significance of the statement 'Everything aside from Allah perishes' in Islamic theology?

hadith-eng: "I sat with the Prophet (ﷺ) more than one-hundred times. His Companions used to recite poetry and talk about things that occurred during Jahiliyyah, and he would remain silent, and sometimes he would smile along with them."
question: How did the Prophet (ﷺ) interact with his companions during their discussions of poetry and pre-Islamic events?

hadith-eng: from his father that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "It is better that one of you fill his insides with puss than to fill it with poetry."
question: What is the significance of avoiding excessive indulgence in poetry according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "It is better that one of you fill his insides with puss than to fill it with poetry."
question: What is the significance of avoiding excessive indulgence in poetry according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Indeed Allah detests the excessive among men, who slaps his tongue around like the cow slaps his tongue."
question: What behavior is disliked by Allah according to the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prohibited that a man sleep on a terrace without something to obstruct him (so that he will not roll off and fall)."
question: What safety precautions are advised for sleeping in elevated places?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to take care of us by preaching during the days fearing that we may get bored."
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) ensure that his followers remained engaged and attentive to his teachings?

hadith-eng: "I asked 'Aishah and Umm Salamah about which deed did the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) like to do most. They said: 'Whatever he could do regularly, even if it was little.'"
question: What is the significance of consistency in performing good deeds in Islam?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Cover the vessels, tie the water-skins, close the doors, extinguish the torches, for indeed the mischief-makers (vermin) may drag away the wick, causing a fire for the inhabitants of the house."
question: What precautions should be taken at night to ensure safety according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "When you travel through fertile land, then give the camels their fill of the land, and when you travel through drought, then hasten while they are fresh, and when you camp late, then stay away from the road, for indeed it is the route of the beasts and the abode of poisonous vermin in the night."
question: What guidance is provided for traveling with camels through fertile land?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "There are six courtesies due from a Muslim to another Muslim: To give Salam to him when he meets him, to accept his invitation when he invites him, to reply to him when he sneezes, to visit him when he is ill, to follow his funeral when he dies, and to love for him what he loves for himself."
question: How important is it to greet fellow Muslims with Salam?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "There are six things due from the believer to another believer: Visiting him when he is ill, attending (his funeral) to him when he dies, accepting his invitation when he invites, giving him Salam when he meets him, replying to him when he sneezes, and wishing him well when he is absent and when he is present."
question: How should a believer respond to an invitation from another believer?

hadith-eng: from Nafi: "A man sneezed beside Ibn 'Umar and said: 'Al-Hamdulillah Was-Salamu 'Ala Rasulillah. (All praise is due to Allah, and peace upon the Messenger of Allah)'. So Ibn 'Umar said: 'I too say Al-Hamdulillah Was-Salamu 'Ala Rasulillah, but this is not what the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) taught us. He taught us to say: "Al-Hamdulillah 'Ala Kulli Hal (All praise is due to Allah in every circumstance)."
question: How did Ibn 'Umar respond to the man who added 'Was-Salamu 'Ala Rasulillah' after sneezing?

hadith-eng: The Jews used to sneeze in the presence of the Prophet (ﷺ) hoping that he would say: 'Yarhamukumullah (May Allah have mercy upon you).' So he said: 'Yahdikumullahu Wa Yuslihu Balakum (May Allah guide you and rectify your affairs).'"
question: What phrase did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) use to respond to the sneezes of the Jews?

hadith-eng: that he was with some people on a journey, and a man among the people sneezed and he said: "As-Salamu Alaikum (peace be upon you)." So he (Salim) said: "'Alaika Wa 'Ala Ummik (upon you and upon your mother)." It seemed as if that bothered the man, so he said: "Indeed I have not said except what the Prophet (ﷺ) said; a man sneezed in the presence of the Prophet (ﷺ) and said: 'As-Salamu 'Alaikum (peace be upon you)' so the Prophet (ﷺ) said: ''Alaika Wa 'Ala Ummik (upon you and upon your mother). When one of you sneezes let him say: "Al-Hamdulillahi Rabbil-'Alamin (All praise is due to the Lord of all that exists)" and let the one responding to him say: Yarhamukallah (May Allah have mercy upon you)" and let him reply: Yaghfirullah Li Walakum (May Allah forgive me and you both)."
question: What should a person say after sneezing according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "When one of you sneezes let him say: 'Al-Hamdulillahi 'Ala Kulli Hal (All praise is due to Allah in every circumstance).' And let the one replying to him say: "Yarhamukallah (May Allah have mercy upon you).' And let him say to him: 'Yahdikumullah Wa Yuslihu Balakum (May Allah guide you and rectify your affairs).'"
question: What should a person say in response to someone who has sneezed and praised Allah?

hadith-eng: that two men sneezed in the presence of the Prophet (ﷺ); he responded to one of them and did not respond to the other. The one who was not responded to said: "O Messenger of Allah! You responded to this person and did not respond to me?' So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "He praised Allah while you did not praise Him."
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) demonstrate the importance of gratitude in this situation?

hadith-eng: from his father: "A man sneezed in the presence of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) while I was present, so the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Yarhamukallah (May Allah have mercy upon you).' Then he sneezed a second and third time. So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "This man is suffering from a cold.'"
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) respond to someone sneezing multiple times?

hadith-eng: from his mother, from her father, who said: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Reply three times to the sneezing person. If he (sneezes) more, then if you wish reply and if you do not then do not.'"
question: What is the etiquette of responding to someone who sneezes more than three times?

hadith-eng: that when the Prophet (ﷺ) would sneeze, he would cover his face with his hand or with his garment, and muffle the sound with it.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) demonstrate modesty and consideration for others when sneezing?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "The sneeze is from Allah and the yawn is from Ash-Shaitan. So when one of you yawns let him cover his mouth with his hand. For when he says 'Ah, Ah' Ash-Shaitan laughs from inside his opening." [And indeed Allah loves the sneeze and He dislikes the Yawn, so when a man says Ah, Ah when yawning, indeed Ash-Shaitan laughs from inside his opening."]
question: Why is sneezing considered to be from Allah in Islamic belief?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Indeed Allah loves sneezing and He dislikes the yawn. So when one of you sneezes and says 'Al-Hamdulillah (All praise is due to Allah),' then it is a right due from every one who hears him to say: 'Yarhamukallah (May Allah have mercy upon you)' As for yawning then when one of you yawns let him suppress it as much as possible and not say: "Hah Hah' for that is only from Ash-Shaitan laughing at him."
question: Why is it important for others to respond with 'Yarhamukallah' when someone sneezes?

hadith-eng: from 'Adi - and he is Ibn Thabit - from his father, from his grandfather - [from the Prophet (ﷺ)]: "Sneezing, dozing and yawning during Salat, and menstruation, regurgitation and nosebleeds are from Ash-Shaitan."
question: How does sneezing or yawning during prayer relate to spiritual distractions?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Let one of you not have his brother stand from his seat then sit in it."
question: How does Islam view the act of displacing someone from their seat for personal convenience?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Let one of you not have his brother stand from his seat then sit in it."
question: How does Islam emphasize respect for others' personal space and belongings in social settings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "A man has more right to his seat. If he leaves for some need of his, then he returns, then he has more right to his seat."
question: How should one behave if they temporarily leave their seat in a public setting?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "It is not lawful for a man to separate two people except with their permission."
question: How does Islamic teaching address the issue of intervening in personal interactions between people?

hadith-eng: "There was no person more beloved to them than the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)." [He said:] "And they would not stand when they saw him because they knew that he disliked that."
question: How did the companions express their respect for the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) in their actions?

hadith-eng: that Mu'awiyah came out and 'Abdullah bin Az-Zubair and Ibn Safwan stood for him when they saw him, so he said: "Sit, I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) saying: 'Whoever wishes that he be received by men standing then, let him take his seat in the Fire.'"
question: How does the desire for recognition and standing among people relate to one's spiritual well-being?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Five are from the Fitrah: Cutting the pubic hair, circumcision, paring the mustache, plucking the under arm hair and trimming the fingernails."
question: Why is circumcision included in the practices of Fitrah?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "Ten are from the Fitrah: Paring the mustache, leaving the beard to grow, Siwak, cleaning the nose with water, paring the fingernails, washing the knuckles, plucking the underarm hair, shaving the pubic hairs, and Intiqas with water."
question: Why is maintaining personal hygiene emphasized in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: from the Prophet (ﷺ), that he (ﷺ) fixed the time as every forty nights for them to trimming the fingernails, taking from the mustache, and shaving the pubic hairs.
question: How often should one take from the mustache according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "[The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)] fixed the time for us paring the mustache, trimming the fingernails, shaving the pubic hairs and plucking the underarm hairs - that we not leave it for more than forty days."
question: Why is there a specified time limit for certain grooming practices in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "The Prophet (ﷺ) would pare, or take from his mustache, and Ibrahim Khalilur-Rahman would do it (as well)."
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) maintain his personal grooming habits?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Whoever does not take from his mustache, then he is not from us."
question: How does personal grooming relate to the identity of a Muslim according to Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: from his father, from his grandfather that he Prophet (ﷺ) would take from his beard; from its breadth and its length.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) maintain his beard according to Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Trim the mustache and leave the beard to grow."
question: What is the significance of trimming the mustache in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) ordered trimming the mustache and leaving the beard to grow.
question: Why is it important to follow the Prophet's guidance on personal grooming?

hadith-eng: from his paternal uncle, that he saw the Prophet (ﷺ) reclining in the Masjid, and placing one of his feet atop another.
question: How did the Prophet (ﷺ) physically position himself while in the mosque according to this narration?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prohibited Ishtimal As-Samma, Al-Ihtiba in one garment, and that a man raise one of his feet atop the other while he is reclining on his back."
question: Why might certain ways of sitting or reclining be discouraged in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prohibited Ishtimal As-Samma, Al-Ihtiba in one garment, and that a man raise one of his feet atop the other while he is reclining on his back."
question: Why might certain ways of sitting or reclining be discouraged in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) saw a man laying on his stomach so he said: "Indeed such laying is not loved by Allah."
question: Why might certain physical positions be discouraged in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "My father narrated to me from my grandfather, who said: 'I said: "O Messenger of Allah! Regarding our 'Awrah, what of it must we cover and what of it may we leave?" He said: "Protect your 'Awrah except from your wife or what your right hand possesses."' He said: "What about a man with another man?" He said: "If you are able to not let anyone see it, then do so." I said: "What about a man when he is alone?" He said: "Allah is most deserving of being shy from Him."
question: How should one behave regarding their 'Awrah when they are alone?

hadith-eng: "I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) reclining upon as pillow, on his left side."
question: What significance does the posture of reclining have in Islamic tradition or teachings?

hadith-eng: "I saw the Prophet (ﷺ) reclining upon a pillow."
question: How does the Prophet's (ﷺ) use of a pillow reflect on his approach to comfort and simplicity?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "A man is not lead in his dominion, and his seat of honor in his house is not sat in without his permission."
question: Why is it important to seek permission before sitting in someone's seat of honor in their home?

hadith-eng: "I heard my father Buraidah saying: 'I was walking with the Prophet (ﷺ) when a man came to him with a donkey, so he said: "O Messenger of Allah! Ride" and the man moved toward the back. The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "No, you have more right to the front of your beast, unless you allot it for me." He said: "I have allotted it for you.'" He said: 'So he rode.'"
question: How does this narration illustrate the concept of rights and ownership in Islam?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Do you have Anmat?" I said: "Where would we get Anmat from?" He said: "Soon you will have Anmat" He said: "I would say to my wife: 'Remove your Anmat from my sight.' But she would say: 'Did not the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) say: "Indeed you shall soon have Anmat?" He said: "So I left it."
question: How did the companions of the Prophet (ﷺ) respond to his prophecies or statements about future events?

hadith-eng: from his father who said: "I guided Allah's Prophet (ﷺ) and Al-Hasan and Al-Husain, on his gray mule until I brought him to the apartment of the Prophet (ﷺ), this one was in front of him, and this one behind him."
question: What significance does the use of a mule have in the context of transportation during the time of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: "I asked the Messenger Of Allah (ﷺ) about the unintentional glance, so he ordered me that I divert my sight."
question: How should one react when they accidentally see something they should not?

hadith-eng: from his father (from the Prophet (ﷺ)) who said: "O 'Ali! Do not follow a look with a look, the first is for you, but the next is not for you."
question: Why is the first look considered permissible, but subsequent looks are not?

hadith-eng: to Ibn Shihab, that Umm Salamah narrated to him, that she and Maimunah were with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), she said: "So when we were with him, Ibn Umm Maktum came, and he entered upon him, and that was after veiling had been ordered for us. So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Veil yourselves from him.' So I said: 'O Messenger of Allah! Is he not blind such that he can not see us or recognize us?' So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Are you two blind such that you can not see him?'"
question: How does the concept of modesty apply to interactions between men and women in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: from the freed slave of 'Amr bin Al-'As that 'Amr bin Al-'As sent him to 'Ali seeking his permission to enter upon Asma bint Umais, so he permitted him. When he was finished from what he needed, the freed slave of 'Amr bin Al-'As asked about that, so he said: "Indeed the Prophet (ﷺ) prohibited us - or - prohibited that we enter upon women, without the permission of their husbands."
question: Why is it important to have the husband's permission before visiting his wife according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "I have not left among the people after me, a Fitnah more harmful upon men than women."
question: How does the presence of women serve as a test or trial for men in Islam?

hadith-eng: that he heard Mu'awiyah giving a Khutbah in Al-Madinah, and saying: "Where are your scholars, O people of Al-Madinah? [Indeed] I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) forbidding from these locks (of hair), and saying: 'The Children of Isra'il were only ruined when their women used them.'"
question: What are the consequences mentioned for a community when its women adopt certain practices?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) cursed the women who practice tattooing and those who seek to be tattooed, the women who remove hair from their faces seeking beautification by changing the creation of Allah.
question: How does Islam view altering one's physical appearance for beautification?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "Allah's curse is upon the woman who lengthens hair and the women who seeks to have her hair lengthened, and the woman who tattoos and the woman who seeks to have her herself tattooed."
question: What are the consequences mentioned for women who engage in practices like hair lengthening and tattooing?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) cursed the women who imitate men and the men who imitate women."
question: Why might imitating the opposite gender be discouraged in Islam?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) cursed those men who behave effeminately and those women whose behavior is masculine."
question: How does Islam view the alteration of natural gender characteristics?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "Every eye commits adultery, and when the woman uses perfume and she passes by a gathering, then she is like this and that.'" Meaning an adulteress.
question: How does Islam view the concept of adultery in relation to one's actions and intentions?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Fragrance for men is that which its scent is apparent and its color is hidden, and fragrance for women is that which its color is visible and its scent is hidden." (Meaning when leaving the home as indicated by the previous chapter. As far as in the presence of the husband, then the woman may wear fragrant perfume.)
question: How should women apply fragrance when leaving the home according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "The Prophet (ﷺ) said [to me]: 'Indeed the best fragrance for men is what's scent is apparent and its color is hidden, and the best fragrance for women is what's color is visible and its scent is hidden.' And he prohibited Mitharatil-Urjawan (Mitharah was some type of saddle cloth. Some of the people of knowledge say it was a certain kind of cloth made of silk, and it preceded earlier under no. 1760. They disagree over Al-Urjawan, and perhaps it means whatever is red, meaning the Red Mitahrah, see Tuhfat Al-Ahwadhi)."
question: What are the characteristics of the best fragrance for women according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Anas would not refuse perfume, and Anas said: 'Indeed the Prophet (ﷺ) would not refuse perfume."
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) demonstrate his appreciation for perfume?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "There are three that are not refused: Cushions, oils [Duhn (fragrance)], and milk."
question: What is the significance of accepting gifts or offerings in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'When one of you is given some fragrance then do not refuse it, for indeed it comes from Paradise."
question: How is fragrance associated with Paradise in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "A woman is not to touch a woman such that she can describe her to her husband as if he is looking at her."
question: How does this teaching address the issue of describing others to one's spouse?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'A man is not to look at the 'Awrah of a man, and a woman is not to look at the 'Awrah of a woman. A man is not to be alone with a man under one garment, and a woman is not to be alone with a woman under one garment.'"
question: What is the significance of modesty in interactions between individuals of the same gender?

hadith-eng: from his father, from his grandfather, who said: "I said: 'O Prophet of Allah! Regarding our 'Awrah, what of it must we cover and what of it may we leave?' He said: 'Protect your 'Awrah except from your wife or what your right hand possesses.' He said: "I said: 'O Messenger of Allah! What about when some people are with others?' He said: 'If you are able to not let anyone see it then do not let them see it.'" He said: "I said: 'O Prophet of Allah! What about when one of us is alone?' He said: 'Allah is more deserving of being shy from Him than the people.'"
question: How should one behave regarding their 'Awrah when they are alone?

hadith-eng: about his grandfather Jarhad, he said: "The Prophet (ﷺ) passed by Jarhad in the Masjid and his thigh was exposed, so he said: 'Indeed the thigh is 'Awrah.'"
question: Why is it important to cover the 'Awrah in Islam?

hadith-eng: from his father, from the Prophet (ﷺ) who said: "The thigh is 'Awrah."
question: How does the concept of 'Awrah influence modesty in Islam?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "The thigh is 'Awrah."
question: How does the concept of 'Awrah influence the dress code in Islam?

hadith-eng: "Ibn Jarhad informed me from his father, that the Prophet (ﷺ) passed by him while his thigh was exposed, so the Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Cover your thigh, for indeed it is 'Awrah.'"
question: Why is it important to cover parts of the body considered 'Awrah in Islam?

hadith-eng: "I heard Sa'eed bin Musayyab saying: 'Indeed Allah is Tayyib (good) and he loves Tayyib (what is good), and He is Nazif (clean) and He loves cleanliness, He is Karim (kind) and He loves kindness, He is Jawad (generous) and He loves generosity. So clean' - I think he said - 'your courtyards, and do not resemble the Jews.'" He said: "I mentioned that to Muhajir bin Mismar, and he said: "Amir bin Sa'd [bin Abi Waqqas] narrated it to me from his father from the Prophet (ﷺ), similarly, except that he did not say: "Clean your courtyards."
question: How does this narration emphasize the importance of cleanliness in Islam?

hadith-eng: from Laith, from Nafi, from Ibn 'Umar that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Beware of nakedness! For indeed there are with you, those who do not part from you except at the place of defecation, and when a man goes into his wife. So be shy of them and honor them."
question: How does Islamic teaching address the concept of being aware of unseen beings in daily life?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, then he is not to let his wife enter the Hammam, and whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, then he is not to enter the Hammam without an Izar. And whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, then he is not to sit at a spread in which Khamr is circulated."
question: What is the significance of wearing an Izar when entering a Hammam?

hadith-eng: from 'Aishah, that the Prophet (ﷺ) prohibitied the men and women from the Hammamat (plural of Hammam), then he permitted it for the men in Izar."
question: Under what conditions did the Prophet permit men to use Hammamat?

hadith-eng: that some women from the inhabitants of Hims, or from the inhabitants of Ash-Sham entered upon 'Aishah, so she said: "Are you those whose women enter the Hammamat? I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) saying: 'No woman removes her garments in other than the house of her husband except that she has torn the screen between herself and her Lord.'"
question: How does Islam view the act of women removing their garments outside their husband's home?

hadith-eng: "I heard Abu Talhah saying: 'I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) saying: "The angels do not enter a house in which there is a dog or an object of images."
question: How do dogs and images affect the presence of angels in a household?

hadith-eng: that Rafi' bin Ishaq informed him, saying: "I and 'Abdullah bin Abi Talhah entered upon Abu Sa'eed Al-Khudri to visit him. So Abu Sa'eed said: 'The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) informed us: "The angels do not enter a house in which there is an image or a picture."
question: How does the presence of images or pictures in a house affect its spiritual environment?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Jibra'il came to me and said: "Indeed I had come to you last night, and nothing prevented me from entering upon you at the house you were in, except that there were images of men at the door of the house, and there was a curtain screen with imagines on it, and there was a dog in the house. So go and sever the head of the image that is at the door so that it will become like a tree stump, and go and cut the screen and make two throw-cushions to be sat upon, and go and expel the dog." So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did so, and the dog was a puppy belonging to Al-Husain or Al-Hasan which was under his belongings, so he ordered him to expel it.
question: Why might the presence of a dog in a house be significant in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: "A man passed by while wearing two red garments. He gave Salam to the Prophet (ﷺ) but he did not return the Salam."
question: How does the color or type of clothing affect social interactions in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prohibited the gold ring, Al-Qassi, Al-Mitharah, and Al-Ji'ah (beer)."
question: Why might wearing a gold ring be discouraged in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) ordered us with seven things and he forbade us from seven. He ordered us to follow the funeral, visit the ill, reply to the sneezing person, accept the invitation, assist the oppressed, to help the one who made an oath, and to return the Salam. And he forbade us from seven things: From the gold ring, or ringlets of gold, silver vessels, wearing silk, Ad-Dibaj, Al-Istabraq, And Al-Qassi."
question: What are the seven things that Muslims are forbidden from according to the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Wear white, for indeed it is very pure and cleaner, and shroud your dead in it.'"
question: Why is white considered a pure and clean color in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "I saw the Prophet (ﷺ) on a clear night, so I looked at the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and at the moon, and he was wearing a red Hullah, and he looked better than the moon to me."
question: What significance does the comparison between the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) and the moon hold in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: "I saw the Messenger of Allah wearing two green Burud."
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) choice of clothing from this narration?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) went out during the morning wearing a Mirt made of black hair."
question: What is a Mirt and what significance does it hold in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: that his grandmothers Safiyyah bint 'Ulaibah and Dhuhaibah bint 'Ulaibah narrated to him, from Qailah bint Makhramah - and they were her wet nurses and Qailah was the grandmother of their father - his mother's mother - she said: "We came to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)" and she mentioned the Hadith in its entirety; "until a man came when the sun had rose up, so he said: "As-Salamu 'Alaika O Messenger of Allah!' So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Wa 'Alaikas-Salamu Wa Rahmatullah' and upon him - meaning the Prophet (ﷺ) - were two tattered cloths, which had been dyed with saffron and had faded, and he had a small date-palm branch with him."
question: How did the Prophet respond to greetings from others, and what does this teach about his character?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prohibited saffron for men.
question: Why might certain colors or materials be prohibited for men in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "The Prophet (ﷺ) saw a man wearing Khuluq and said: 'Go and wash it, then wash it, then do not use it again.'"
question: How does Islamic teaching address the use of specific perfumes or scents?

hadith-eng: from Ibn 'Umar who said: "I heard 'Umar mentioning that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Whoever wears silk in the world he shall not wear it in the Hereafter.'"
question: How does the choice of clothing in this life relate to the rewards or consequences in the Hereafter?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) distributed some cloaks but he did not give anything to Makhramah. Makhramah said: 'O my son! Let us go to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).' So I went with him. He said: 'Enter and call him for me.'So I called the Prophet (ﷺ) for him, then the Prophet (ﷺ) came out wearing one of the cloaks. He (ﷺ) said: 'I kept this one for you.'" He said: "So he looked at him and said: 'Makhramah is pleased.'"
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) approach to distributing gifts or resources among his companions?

hadith-eng: from his father, from his grandfather who said: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Indeed Allah loves to see the results of his favors upon His Slaves.'"
question: How can individuals show gratitude for the blessings they receive from Allah?

hadith-eng: from his father: "An-Najashi gave the Prophet (ﷺ) two black plain Khuff. So he wore them, then he performed Wudu and wiped over them."
question: How does the practice of wiping over Khuff relate to the performance of Wudu?

hadith-eng: from his father, from his grandfather: "The Prophet (ﷺ) prohibited plucking gray hair. And he said: "It is the Muslim's light.'"
question: Why might plucking gray hair be discouraged in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "The one whose counsel is sought is entrusted."
question: How does trust play a role when someone seeks advice from another person?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'The one whose council is sought is entrusted.'"
question: How is trust emphasized in the context of giving advice in Islam?

hadith-eng: from their father that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "An omen is in three: A woman, a dwelling, and a (riding) beast."
question: How does the concept of omens relate to women, dwellings, and riding beasts in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Whenever there are three of you, then let two not converse in exclusion of their companion."
question: How does excluding someone from a conversation affect social relationships in a group setting?

hadith-eng: that Abu Juhaifah said: "I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) (he was) white and turning grey. Al-Hasan bin 'Ali resembles him most. He had promised thirteen young she-camels for us, so we went to get them. When we arrived he had died without giving us anything. So when Abu Bakr (became the Khalifah) he said: 'If there is anyone to whom the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) made a promise, then let him come forth.' I stood to inform him about it, and he ordered that they be given to us."
question: How is the resemblance between Al-Hasan bin 'Ali and the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) highlighted?

hadith-eng: that Abu Juhaifah said: "I saw the Prophet (ﷺ), and Al-Hasan bin 'Ali resembles him the most."
question: What is the significance of physical resemblance to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: "I did not hear the Prophet (ﷺ) mentioning both of his parents (that is including both in the saying "May my father and mother be ransomed for you") for anyone other than Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas."
question: Who was Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas and what was his importance in early Islamic history?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did not mention both of his parents for anyone except Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas. On the Day of Uhud he said: 'Shoot, may my father and mother be ransomed for you.' And he said to him: 'Shoot! O young man.'"
question: Who was Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas and what was his role in the Battle of Uhud?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) mentioned both of his parents to me on the Day of Uhud."
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) express his emotions or sentiments during significant events?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said to him: "O my little son."
question: How does the use of affectionate language by the Prophet influence the relationship between him and his companions?

hadith-eng: from his father, from his grandfather that the Prophet (ﷺ) ordered naming the child on the seventh day, removing the harm from him, and Al-'Aqq (removing the hair and slaughtering the animal for 'Aqiqah).
question: What practices are recommended for a newborn on the seventh day according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "The most loved names to Allah are 'Abdullah and 'Abdur-Rahman."
question: Why might certain names be favored by Allah in Islam?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "The most loved names to Allah are 'Abdullah and 'Abdur-Rahman."
question: Why might certain names be favored by Allah in Islam?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "I forbid naming with Rafi, Barakah and Yasar."
question: Why might certain names be prohibited or discouraged in Islam?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Do not name your boy Rabah, nor Aflah, nor Yasar, nor Najih, so that it may be said: 'Is he there?' and it may be said: 'No.'"
question: Why might certain names be discouraged in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that Abu Hurairah conveyed to him that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "The most despicable (Akhna) name to Allah on the Day of Judgement is that of a man named King of Kings. (Malikil-Amlak)."
question: Why is the name 'King of Kings' considered despicable in the sight of Allah?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) changed the name of 'Asiyah, he said: "You are Jamilah."
question: How does the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) approach the concept of names and their meanings?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) would change abhorrent names."
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) approach names that were considered inappropriate or negative?

hadith-eng: from his father that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "I have some names: I am Muhammad, I am Ahmad, I am Al-Mahi, the one by whom Allah wipes out disbelief, I am Al-Hasir, the one whom the people are gathered at his feet, and I am Al-'Aqib, the one after whom there is no Prophet."
question: What is the significance of the name Al-Mahi in relation to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) prohibited that one use his name and his Kunyah; naming themselves Muhammad Abul-Qasim.
question: What is the significance of the name Muhammad in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ): "When you name yourself after me, then do not use my Kunyah."
question: Why might it be important to avoid using specific titles or names that are associated with the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: that he said: "O Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)! If I have a son after you do you think I could name him your Kunyah?" He said: "Yes." So he said: "So that was permitted for me."
question: What is the concept of Kunyah in Islamic culture?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Indeed some poetry is wisdom"
question: How can poetry serve as a medium for imparting wisdom?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Indeed some poetry is wisdom".
question: How can poetry serve as a medium for imparting wisdom and knowledge?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had a Minbar placed in the Masjid for Hassan to stand to boast (poetically) about the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)" - or she said: "to defend the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). And the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Indeed Allah has aided Hassan with the holy spirit (Jibril) as he boasts about - or - defends the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).'"
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) view the role of Hassan in defending him through poetry?

hadith-eng:
that the Prophet (ﷺ) entered Makkah during 'Umratil-Qada and 'Abdullah bin Rawahah was walking in front of him reciting verses of poetry.
"O tribes of disbelievers get out of his way - today we will strike you about its revelation; a strike that removes the heads from the shoulders - and makes the friend not concerned about his friend."
'Umar said to him: "O Ibn Rawahah! Before the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), and in the sanctuary of Allah you utter poetry?" the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Leave him O 'Umar! For it is quicker upon them than the raining arrow."
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) respond to the recitation of poetry in his presence?

hadith-eng: from his father, that 'Aishah was asked: "Did the Prophet (ﷺ) used to say any poetry?" She said: "He would say parables with the poetry of Ibn Rawahah, saying: 'News shall come to you from where you did not expect it.'"
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) use parables in his teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "The best statement spoken by the Arab is the saying of Labid: 'Everything aside from Allah perishes.'"
question: How does the concept of the impermanence of all things except Allah influence a Muslim's worldview?

hadith-eng: "I sat with the Prophet (ﷺ) more than one-hundred times. His Companions used to recite poetry and talk about things that occurred during Jahiliyyah, and he would remain silent, and sometimes he would smile along with them."
question: What was the Prophet's (ﷺ) demeanor when his companions talked about the times of ignorance?

hadith-eng: from his father that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "It is better that one of you fill his insides with puss than to fill it with poetry."
question: How does the comparison between filling oneself with pus and poetry highlight the importance of content in one's life?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "It is better that one of you fill his insides with puss than to fill it with poetry."
question: How does the comparison between filling one's insides with pus and poetry highlight the potential negative impact of poetry?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Indeed Allah detests the excessive among men, who slaps his tongue around like the cow slaps his tongue."
question: How is excessive behavior among men described in the teachings of Islam?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prohibited that a man sleep on a terrace without something to obstruct him (so that he will not roll off and fall)."
question: Why is it important to have a barrier when sleeping on a terrace?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to take care of us by preaching during the days fearing that we may get bored."
question: What methods can be used to prevent boredom in religious education and preaching?

hadith-eng: "I asked 'Aishah and Umm Salamah about which deed did the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) like to do most. They said: 'Whatever he could do regularly, even if it was little.'"
question: How does the regularity of actions impact their value in the eyes of Allah?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Cover the vessels, tie the water-skins, close the doors, extinguish the torches, for indeed the mischief-makers (vermin) may drag away the wick, causing a fire for the inhabitants of the house."
question: Why is it important to cover vessels and tie water-skins in the context of household safety?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "When you travel through fertile land, then give the camels their fill of the land, and when you travel through drought, then hasten while they are fresh, and when you camp late, then stay away from the road, for indeed it is the route of the beasts and the abode of poisonous vermin in the night."
question: How should one manage travel through drought conditions according to the teachings?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "There are six courtesies due from a Muslim to another Muslim: To give Salam to him when he meets him, to accept his invitation when he invites him, to reply to him when he sneezes, to visit him when he is ill, to follow his funeral when he dies, and to love for him what he loves for himself."
question: What is the significance of accepting invitations in Islam?

hadith-eng: that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "There are six things due from the believer to another believer: Visiting him when he is ill, attending (his funeral) to him when he dies, accepting his invitation when he invites, giving him Salam when he meets him, replying to him when he sneezes, and wishing him well when he is absent and when he is present."
question: What is the significance of giving Salam when meeting another believer?

hadith-eng: from Nafi: "A man sneezed beside Ibn 'Umar and said: 'Al-Hamdulillah Was-Salamu 'Ala Rasulillah. (All praise is due to Allah, and peace upon the Messenger of Allah)'. So Ibn 'Umar said: 'I too say Al-Hamdulillah Was-Salamu 'Ala Rasulillah, but this is not what the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) taught us. He taught us to say: "Al-Hamdulillah 'Ala Kulli Hal (All praise is due to Allah in every circumstance)."
question: What phrase did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) teach to say after sneezing?

hadith-eng: The Jews used to sneeze in the presence of the Prophet (ﷺ) hoping that he would say: 'Yarhamukumullah (May Allah have mercy upon you).' So he said: 'Yahdikumullahu Wa Yuslihu Balakum (May Allah guide you and rectify your affairs).'"
question: What is the significance of the phrase 'Yahdikumullahu Wa Yuslihu Balakum' in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: that he was with some people on a journey, and a man among the people sneezed and he said: "As-Salamu Alaikum (peace be upon you)." So he (Salim) said: "'Alaika Wa 'Ala Ummik (upon you and upon your mother)." It seemed as if that bothered the man, so he said: "Indeed I have not said except what the Prophet (ﷺ) said; a man sneezed in the presence of the Prophet (ﷺ) and said: 'As-Salamu 'Alaikum (peace be upon you)' so the Prophet (ﷺ) said: ''Alaika Wa 'Ala Ummik (upon you and upon your mother). When one of you sneezes let him say: "Al-Hamdulillahi Rabbil-'Alamin (All praise is due to the Lord of all that exists)" and let the one responding to him say: Yarhamukallah (May Allah have mercy upon you)" and let him reply: Yaghfirullah Li Walakum (May Allah forgive me and you both)."
question: How should one respond to a sneeze to invoke blessings and forgiveness?
